threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9422804
It depends on the series, honestly.
If the games have an obvious chronology, I'll go with the first one in canon order (Resident Evil Zero or Starfox). If it's a series with a bunch of mostly-unrelated entries, I'll start with what people widely agree is the archetypal entry (So Ocarina of Time or Castlevania SotN).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9424741
While I am a Macfag, let's not pretend for a second that the backwards-compatibility in Windows isn't far, far better than Mac OS.

Windows NT was basically stolen OS/2 code so it makes sense that it would not run DOS programs. The way Microsoft got around that when the time came for Windows XP was by using a DOS emulator that ran in the background (NTVDM, or "NT Virtual DOS Machine"). You basically paravirtualized the old DOS shit to get it to work with Microsoft's OS/2... I mean Windows XP code. This is not too dissimilar to what Apple did with 68k code in System 7 on PowerPC processors. I would not really call this solution a monkey patch, it's baked into the OS and it works pretty well. Meanwhile I can't even run 32-bit Intel OSX applications on the current version of Mac OS, let alone something like Brood War (which runs fine on Windows 10).

>XP stuff is rough on win7
I find that most non-driver software that was designed for Windows XP will run fine on Windows Vista/7/8/10/11. I just set up my nephew with a whole bunch of turn-of-the-millenium games (Rise of Nations, Rome Total War, Knights of the Old Republic, Sim City 4, Civilization IV, Combat Flight Simulator 3, etc) on his Win11 Costco laptop, and everything works flawlessly. This would be a fucking pipe dream on a Mac.

>>9425223

I have an iMac G4 that won't power on, I suspect the issue is with a dead battery or bad power button, but I would like to get it up and running so I can play this game again. >>9426191
>I pray every day for a second japanese economic bubble in my lifetime. We have to go back

It amazes me that there was a time in history where making a $250,000 arcade game (with a real Mazda sports car) was actually profitable for a company. There were actually businesses that bought these huge Ridge Racer arcade machines. And Namco made big money.

Today, you can barely get people to leave their house let alone go to an arcade. But back then? Arcades were filled to the brim with people. It was so popular that Sega and Namco's arcade factories could NOT keep up with demand.

Here's another thing you may not know. Arcade games were so in-demand and so valued that even the mob and organized crime bought expensive arcade machines (instead of land) to hide their money from the government.

What the mob would do is buy the most expensive machines they could get their hands on like a Sega R360, some premium driving game, or whatever. Then take these machines and store them in a barn or some other building in the middle of nowhere. Only a few trusted people would know where they were stored. Then they wait several months to a year, and then resell their machines to get their money back.

That's why you hear all these stories about people finding arcades in "random barns" 20 years later in the countryside in the middle of nowhere. Where no arcades ever existed or were ever close by. Many of these are NOT random finds. They were put there for a reason until organized crime could reclaim them.

Sometimes the mob would get taken down and the arcade machines would get forgotten about in the confusion.

Also the arcade market crashed hard in the late 1990s/early 2000s. So it wasn't even worth the effort to retrieve the arcade machines sitting in barns anymore. A single machine previously worth $10,000 dollars is now worth almost nothing. Arcade owners were literally throwing their arcade cabs into dumpsters. Arcades were shutting down across the West.

You need either an adapter or use an Everdrive to play NTSC games on a PAL console and vice versa
Nintendo consoles don't output the proper colors in non-standard modes. PAL60 and NTSC50 are both equally fucked but it depends on your display whether they'll work or not, some upscalers also don't like em. Gamecube has the exact same issue which is made more infuriating by GCN having official 60hz-only PAL games.
I've had better luck for color compatibility with NTSC games on a PAL console with an adapter than vice versa.
As a fellow european here's a hot protip for you: american games are better due to having a higher framerate. in addition they're also usually cheaper than PAL games due to being less desirable in europe.

>>9426110
>80s
All 1980s games were made by only a handful of people. Usually like 5-20 depending on the game. The big budget games in the old days mostly came down to advertising and manufacturing, hence why Mario 3 is the biggest game of its day despite being created by only 10 people. It's not until the mid-ish 90s when you see this number really start climbing to 40-80 people, and then get increasingly bigger and bigger. Final Fantasy 7 had multiple hundreds of people working on it, which was completely unheard of at the time. It was basically the equivalent of like 10 developers working on 1 game by the standards of the era. And that's probably not even including way more uncredited names from visual effects and computer companies.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: It’s far better than you think
threads.com:
Behold, the Bandai wonderswan. The superior 90s handheld that deserves far more credit than it receives

With a library matching the Dreamcast in number and variety, it’s 200 games cover genres that portable gaming frankly sucked at beforehand.

Here you’ll find some of the best strategy RPGs and fighters handhelds ever had to offer in 99.

Backed by the powerhouse that was square, the console got a lot of big name titles from the developer. Final fantasies, mystery dungeons, and a fucking clock tower- the selection of quality RPGs on the console kicks the shit out of what the gameboy color and NGPC was offering that same year.

Being the first handheld with a widescreen, it made real nice for fighting games and vertical puzzlers.

From pocket fighter to guilty gear, to digimon and one piece, the system has a healthy selection of fun brawlers that play very well on the small screen.

On the note of one piece, the console was notable for its anime tie ins. Bandai was a licensing powerhouse after all.

The system was quite capable too! Handily shitting all over the cpus of the gameboy and neo geo pocket- this was the only system of the 3 that could run a full ass web browser.

Nearly the entire library runs at 75 fps. Why? Idk but it’s quite nice. Games are smooth with lots of animation and fast clean scrolling. Hundreds of sprites dotting the screen without hiccup.
The system is no slouch in audio hardware either. Having a capable synth setup, AND cool ass sample capabilities- it has a sound that when used to full potential reminds me of some neo geo titles.

Despite the device being a properly capable 16 bit handheld for the time, the thing SIPS power. A single AA battery will keep the thing in active gameplay for well over 40 hours. That’s not 40 hours standby- that’s 40 hours of straight gameplay. On ONE battery. Gbc could barely muster 10 on 2 of the things.
This was also a console that only cost about $30 on release.

Both the N64 and Gamecube output non-standard colors when playing PAL games on NTSC consoles and vice versa

So I am one of those people who really turned around with 8. I think my recent love of the SaGa games has made me more accepting of the changes. I do think it's not without issues though, to basically get where you don't need to Draw anymore does require a fair bit of AP grinding certain enemy mobs so you can level up GF abilities. Also scarcity of certain spells just means you need to spend maybe more time than you'd like casting Draw on a boss.
That said I think it's a good game, it's not the best of the PS1 trilogy but it kind of ranks in a decent spot for me. I also like how believable Squall is as a main character. How he's this no nonsense by the books type soldier who wants to focus on his developement, while being surrounded by people who want to do nothing but goof off.

Super Butouden is the one I recommend most. Fun story mode, pretty short. Different than most fighters in that it’s more about being flashy than being technical, but I enjoy it. Wish it came out in the US but the timing was just off

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9425658
skip Butouden 1 and play 2, it's a huge upgrade, like Street Fighter 1 and 2. You can play 3 as well but it was rushed and incomplete, had worse graphics, and the cast used the early Buu saga so it was pretty underwhelming.

Hyper Dimension was a very late game, it used an add-on chip, and it played more like a traditional 2d fighter without screen splitting. But holy shit it's one of the best 2d fighters on the system. Awesome art style, captured the characters really good, but still had great variety. I liked how nearly every fighter had a slightly different look, especially for charging their power, it wasn't just the same generic aura laid behind the sprite like in Butouden.
I mean compared to shit like SF3 and Alpha 2 it played a bit stiff and only had so much animation, but what was in there was beautiful and looked miles ahead of the 4-color sprites in Alpha.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9422756
Trying to get your reputation as high as possible is more difficult than just allowing it to fall into the gutter, but you miss out on a lot of things with low reputation. There are a ton of recruitable characters and events that require high reputation, and very few that require low reputation. The low-rep endings also tend to be pretty bleak, unsurprisingly.

>>9422762
Yeah, they're almost identical.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9422645
Not that anon, but to add, ALI affect bonuses when fighting at day or night if it is too extreme, with low ALI characters performing better at night and high ALI characters at daytime. It's better to shuffle characters in units and let the alignment even out if you aren't going for promotion requirements, but you can keep it in mind when facing enemy units: if you see that an upcoming conga line of enemies has satan himself playing the saxo with ghosts and demons in tow, it's better to hold the fort at a liberated town and push forward at the break of dawn.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9422040
OB64 is great because it introduces a lot of game mechanics that improve the experience: liberating or capturing playing a bigger role, units in a 3x3 grid, unit direction letting you ambush enemies (or be ambushed, exposing your back row), magic mixing if you have 2 or 3 spellcasters, promoting with equipment and more.
I hope that with the remake craze at Square Enix we can get something with the Ogre Battle strategy gameplay, be it a rerelease, remake or new game.
Apparently Reborn has references to PoLC here and there, so I don't lose hope.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I love the game, but it would be even better if:

_ It got rid of the EXP system. Replace it with armor/sword upgrades that you find hidden around or get doing sidequests.
_ It made the lives/mini Links permanent upgrades. Have less of them if they make the game too easy.
_ Add more shortcuts from the starting point to everywhere in the world map, that way there is a better sense of progression as you unlock new passages and getting a game over is less of a pain.
_ Make the game slightly less linear. Death Mountain and the second temple are really the only things you can do out of order, but there should be more of that to make the game more replayable.
_ Spells don't lose effect the moment you exit the screen. As the game is right now there is no point to bother casting fireballs or barrier to deal with an enemy when you can just ignore it. It's especially apparent with enemies that are immune to normal attacks like the Textikes or Wizzrobes.
_ Make the items more than glorified keys. This is the hardest thing to implement, but it would be nice if you could use the items to get for clearing temples for things other the clear roadblocks. The hammer especially should be a weapon that you could use.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: What was it like to grow up in Brazil during the third to sixth console gen?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
It was comfy, but tough.
Most of us had NESes in the 90s (actually famiclones) i grew up with a Dynavision 4.
Whoever owned a super nintendo in the 90s was a BOSS, and owning an n64? your parents were rich as fuck.
SNES became more common in the late 90s
Most kids i knew got their n64s in 2000-2001 ( i got mine in 2001)
With the ps2/GC gen, things started to even out.
i think i got my GC in 2004, at that point at least in my school a lot of kids had ps2s and gamecubes, i remember a single kid that had an xbox and we used to go to his house to play halo.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9424568
I have no idea what you're talking about. Not my problem you've only met retards, maybe that's the sort of people you attract.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9411180
Very nostalgic, but hard.

We couldn't speak english at the time, and games were extremely expensive and thought of as stupid toys. Many parents didn't have the money to buy consoles and games, and some that had simply wouldn't because no.

Since most people couldn't afford consoles, we would all go to game stores that functioned exactly like cyber cafes. Later, the cyber cafes themselves became a phenomenon here.

But these video game stores are etched into any brazilian gamer who lived in this period. You can ask anyone about it, and you'll see him with a nostalgic smile on his face as he tells you about this period

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
>Gadget is hard to describe. Surreal and unsettling would be a good place to start. A weird curio from a bygone era? Yep. An avant-garde art piece? Yeah, probably that too. I'm hesitant to call it a good game, because it's barely a game at all, but I'll certainly say this... it's interesting.

>The game is extremely linear, mostly shuffling you around from location to location with a few things in any given environment to interact with and, once you do, you'll be shuffled off to the next area. This has the effect, intended or not, of making you feel rather uncomfortable as you're given virtually no control over anything. Practically every game amounts to simply doing what the developers intended, but it's rarely as on the nose as it is here, to the point that it feels less like exerting your own will and intellect to reach a desired conclusion that was planned by the developers and more like doing what they want, regardless of what you want. The distinction is arguably superficial but, in this case, it's palpable just the same.

>Graphically the game is a strange mishmash of steampunk, art deco, and some kind of unidentified Eastern Bloc country aesthetic. Things frequently take a turn for the surreal, and you often travel from one location to the next in something approximating an out of body experience - you'll be looking at a monitor of something and then suddenly move through the monitor into that location, for example.

>Adding to the surreal and unsettling quality is a fantastic, otherworldly soundtrack by Koji Ueno. It sometimes reminded me of the work of Akira Yamaoka, with things frequently turning into walls of abstract industrial noise. If the bizarre visuals and storytelling aren't enough to make you uneasy, the music ought to do the trick.

https://www.zombs-lair.com/gadget-collection

threads.com:
Welcome to the Retro Game Gauntlet, gentlemen.


Start at NES, and work through in the following order:

NES
SNES
GB/GBC OR Sega Game Gear
Megadrive/Genesis
Turbografx16
DOS
NeoGeo
GBA OR Sega Master System
Commodore 64 OR Commodore Amiga
Playstation 1 OR Nintendo 64
You have three days to complete the game without assistance (each game gets three days, though RPGs are allowed a week due to length).

Select your system here:
http://cambysses.com/gauntlet

You can also do it manually if you don't trust the random number generator:
http://cambysses.com/gauntlet/games.js

AND BRING ME SCREENSHOTS PARKER


Rules:

1) Savestates are allowed ONLY for the purpose of taking screenshots and ONLY if your emulator/game in question does not have a pause function.

2) Rerolls are allowed under the following conditions:
The game you get requires some sort of hardware functionality that cannot be accurately emulated to complete (eg, Boktai)
The game would otherwise require cheats, hacks, or alteration of the software to complete due to a bug (eg, Cheetahmen II)

3) Playstation 1 games can be given up to 2 weeks to complete if the game is more than 2 discs.

4) If you lose / give up to a game you have to go back one square instead (ie if you gave up a Genesis game, you go back to GB/GBA and continue frome there)

5) For Rule 4, if the game you fail is on the same path as another console, you have the choice to roll for that console instead of dropping down a level.

For games that have a high score or no end, the rule is:
If no high score has been established, set a goal and beat it
if you're playing something another anon already has a high score on, beat their high score
If you are playing extended rpgs/pokemon/whatever you get a week [Depending on the game needs to be asked in thread

>>9421687
bonk 2 is absolutely fantastic. it's a great platformer with great level variety, a lot of replayability for the intricate scoring system and secret bonuses. of all the games in the series, this one is a "must play". i think this game also has the best bonus levels

bonk 1 is also a classic but much more simple, its rougher around the edges but gives more "mario 1" vibes. best soundtrack in the series and oozes with atmosphere. although the graphics are crude, the game has some vibrant colors and a couple striking backgrounds

bonk 3 feels thrown together and the soundtrack is poor, but the co-op is amusing. controls are similar to bonk 2 but juggling is back from bonk 1. levels are the most sprawling in the series but not as tightly designed. boss fights are solid. the crab form from 2 is used a lot more and now you have big/small bonk (the big size is a gimmick). the end of world collectable incentive is poor

bonk 3 is the only one in the series with a debug mode that lets you fuck with bonk's run speed and jump height, and it makes the game more enjoyable

super bonk is decent but the first world is the best one due to branching levels, which is abandoned later on. better than bonk 3 but worse than 1 or 2. improves the candy system at least. levels and bosses drag on a lot...

super bonk 2 is a japan only import and it feels like the type of game bonk 3 should have been. it carries over some features from bonk 2 like the high road low road level design, a greater emphasis on collectables, and the mini boss fights. it's an excellent game but below 2 and 1

the gameboy games are ok. GB 1 is similar to bonk 1, GB 2 is it's own game, has a weird powerup system

the arcade one is tough as balls, but colorful at least. not a fan of the mechanics
